chapter.title: Pretty Little Girls' School: The Structure of Lojban Predicate Phrases

section.title: Lojban content words
section.para: bridirelation to selbri selbrirelation to bridi selbridefinition brididefinition At the center, logically and often physically, of every Lojban statement is one or more words which stand for its main predicate. A statement expresses a relationship between things: the predicate phrase specifies which relationship is referred to. The difference between:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are my mother

section.para: and

interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are my father.

section.para: lies in the different predicates.

brivlatypes brivla as selbri selbribrivla as The simplest kind of predicate phrase is a single Lojban content word: a verb. There are three different varieties of verbs: those which are built into the language (roots), those which are derived from combinations of the roots (compounds), and morphologically opaque words that aren't roots (free words). In addition, there are a few particle-shaped words that are syntactically verbs; these are mentioned in , and discussed in full in .
For the purposes of this chapter, however, all verbs are alike. For example,

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a boat.
That is a ship.
That is a schooner.

section.para: illustrate the three types of verbs (roots, compounds, and free words respectively), but in each case the predicate is denoted by a single word whose meaning can be learned independent of its origins.

The remainder of this chapter will mostly use root words as example verbs, because they are short. However, it is important to keep in mind that wherever a root word appears, it could be replaced by any other kind of verb.

section.title: Simple tanru
section.para: tanrudefinition tanrusimple Beyond the single verb, a predicate phrase may consist of two verbs placed together. When a predicate is built in this way from more than one verb, it is called a tanru, a word with no single English equivalent. The nearest analogue to tanru in English are combinations of two nouns such as lemon tree. There is no way to tell just by looking at the phrase lemon tree exactly what it refers to, even if you know the meanings of lemon and tree by themselves. As English-speakers, we must simply know that it refers to a tree which bears lemons as fruits. A person who didn't know English very well might think of it as analogous to brown tree and wonder, What kind of tree is lemon-colored?

adjective-noun combinationwith tanru adverb-verb combinationwith tanru In Lojban, tanru are also used for the same purposes as English adjective-noun combinations like big boy and adverb-verb combinations like quickly run. This is a consequence of Lojban not distinguishing between categories such as noun, verb, adjective, or adverb. English words belonging to any of these categories are syntactically identical in Lojban. Here are some examples of tanru:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a lemon tree.
John is a big boy.
I am quick at running./I run quickly.

section.para: Note that pelnimre is a compound for lemon; it is derived from pelxu, yellow, and nimre, citrus. Note also that sutra can mean fast/quick or quickly depending on its use:
shows sutra used to translate an adjective, whereas in it is translating an adverb. (Another correct translation of , however, would be I am a quick runner.)

tertaueffect on meaning of tanru tanruprimary meaning of The most important rule for use in interpreting tanru is that the latter component carries the primary meaning. A pelnimre tricu is primarily a tree, and only secondarily is it connected with lemons in some way. For this reason, an alternative translation of would be:

example.para: That is a lemon type of tree.

section.para: This type of relationship between the components of a tanru is fundamental to the tanru concept.

modifierseltau as seltaueffect on meaning of tanru tertaudefinition of seltaudefinition of There are special Lojban terms for the two components of a tanru, derived from the place structure of the word tanru. The first component, the modifier, is called the seltau, and the second component, the modificand, is called the tertau. Anything that can serve as a seltau or a tertau is calld a tanru unit.

example.para: That is a tree which is lemon-ish (in the way appropriate to trees)

section.para: would be another possible translation of . In the same way, a more explicit translation of might be:

example.para: John is a boy who is big in the way that boys are big.

section.para: This way that boys are big would be quite different from the way in which elephants are big; big-for-a-boy is small-for-an-elephant.
ambiguity of tanru tanruambiguity of All tanru are ambiguous semantically. Possible translations of:
include:

listitem.para: That is a table which goes (a wheeled table, perhaps).
That is a table owned by one who goes.
That is a table used by those who go (a sports doctor's table?).
That is a table when it goes (otherwise it is a chair?).

section.para: tanruas ambiguous In each case the object referred to is a goer type of table, but the ambiguous type of relationship can mean one of many things. A speaker who uses tanru (and pragmatically most speakers will) takes the risk of being misunderstood. Using tanru is convenient because they are short and expressive; the circumlocution required to squeeze out all ambiguity can require too much effort.
tanrumeaning of No general theory covering the meaning of all possible tanru exists; probably no such theory can exist. However, some regularities obviously do exist:
are parallel tanru, in the sense that the relationship between barda and prenu is the same as that between cmalu and prenu. and contain a partial listing of some types of tanru, with examples.

section.title: Three-part tanru grouping with bo
section.para: The following particle is discussed in this section:
tanru groupingthree-part Consider the English sentence:
What does it mean? Two possible readings are:

example.para: That's a little school for girls.
That's a school for little girls.

section.para: speech rhythmfor grouping in English This ambiguity is quite different from the simple tanru ambiguity described in . We understand that girls' school means a school where girls are the students, and not a school where girls are the teachers or a school which is a girl (!). Likewise, we understand that little girl means girl who is small. This is an ambiguity of grouping. Is girls' school to be taken as a unit, with little specifying the type of girls' school? Or is little girl to be taken as a unit, specifying the type of school? In English speech, different tones of voice, or exaggerated speech rhythm showing the grouping, are used to make the distinction; English writing usually leaves it unrepresented.

Lojban makes no use of tones of voice for any purpose; explicit words are used to do the work. The particle bo (which belongs to class BO) may be placed between the two verbs which are most closely associated. Therefore, a Lojban translation of would be:
might be translated:

The bo is represented in the literal translation by a bracketed hyphen (not to be confused with the bare hyphen used as a placeholder in other glosses) because in written English a hyphen is sometimes used for the same purpose: a big dog-catcher would be quite different from a big-dog catcher (presumably someone who catches only big dogs).

tanru nested within tanru Analysis of and reveals a tanru nested within a tanru. In , the main tanru has a seltau of cmalu and a tertau of nixli bo ckule; the tertau is itself a tanru with nixli as the seltau and ckule as the tertau. In , on the other hand, the seltau is cmalu bo nixli (itself a tanru), whereas the tertau is ckule. This structure of tanru nested within tanru forms the basis for all the more complex types of predicate phrases that will be explained below.
What about ? What does it mean?

tanrudefault left-grouping of left-grouping ruledefinition of The rules of Lojban do not leave this sentence ambiguous, as the rules of English do with . The choice made by the language designers is to say that means the same as . This is true no matter what three verbs are used: the leftmost two are always grouped together. This rule is called the left-grouping rule. Left-grouping in seemingly ambiguous structures is quite common – though not universal – in other contexts in Lojban.
Another way to express the English meaning of and , using parentheses to mark grouping, is:

interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(small type-of girl) type-of school.

section.para: Because type-of is implicit in the Lojban tanru form, it has no Lojban equivalent.
Note: It is perfectly legal, though pointless, to insert bo into a simple tanru:

is a legal Lojban sentence that means exactly the same thing as , and is ambiguous in exactly the same ways. The word bo serves only to resolve grouping ambiguity: it says nothing about the more basic ambiguity present in all tanru.

section.title: Complex tanru grouping
section.para: tanru groupingcomplex If one element of a tanru can be another tanru, why not both elements?

interlinear-gloss.jbo: do mutce bo barda gerku bo kavbu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: You are-a-(very type-of large) (dog type-of capturer).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are a very large dog-catcher.

section.para: In , the predicate is specified by a tanru with seltau mutce bo barda and tertau gerku bo kavbu. It is worth emphasizing once again that this tanru has the same fundamental ambiguity as all other Lojban tanru: the sense in which the dog type-of capturer is said to be very type-of large is not precisely specified. Presumably it is the capturer's body which is large, but theoretically it could be one of their other properties.

prettyEnglish ambiguity of We will now justify the title of this chapter by exploring the ramifications of the phrase pretty little girls' school, an expansion of the tanru used in
to four Lojban verbs. (Although this example has been used in the Loglan Project almost since the beginning – it first appeared in Quine's book Word and Object (1960) – it is actually a mediocre example because of the ambiguity of English pretty; it can mean beautiful, the sense intended here, or it can mean very. Lojban melbi is not subject to this ambiguity: it means only beautiful.)
Here are four ways to group this phrase:

interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-((pretty type-of little) type-of girl) type-of school.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a school for girls who are beautifully small.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(pretty type-of little) (girl type-of school).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a girls' school which is beautifully small.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - cmalu bo nixli - ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(pretty type-of (little type-of girl)) type-of school.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a school for small girls who are beautiful.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - cmalu bo nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-pretty type-of (little type-of (girl type-of school)).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a small school for girls which is beautiful.

section.para:
bofor right-grouping in tanru tanru groupingwith bo right-grouping in tanruwith bo right-grouping ruledefinition of uses a construction which has not been seen before: cmalu bo nixli bo ckule, with two consecutive uses of bo between tanru components. The rule for multiple bo constructions is the opposite of the rule when no bo is present at all: the last two are grouped together. Not surprisingly, this is called the right-grouping rule, and it is associated with every use of
bo in the language. Therefore,

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu bo nixli bo ckule

section.para: means the same as , not . This rule may seem peculiar at first, but one of its consequences is that bo is never necessary between the first two elements of any of the complex tanru presented so far: all of through could have bo inserted between melbi and cmalu with no change in meaning.

section.title: Complex tanru with ke and ke'e
section.para: The following particles are discussed in this section:

tanru groupingwith ke grouping parentheses There is, in fact, a fifth grouping of pretty little girls' school that cannot be expressed with the resources explained so far. To handle it, we must introduce the grouping parenthesis particles,
ke and ke'e (belonging to classes KE and KEhE respectively). Any portion of a predicate phrase sandwiched between these two words is taken to be a single tanru component, independently of what is adjacent to it. Thus, can be rewritten in any of the following ways:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-( pretty little ) girl school.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-( ( pretty little ) girl ) school.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke ke ke melbi cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule ke'e
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-( ( ( pretty little ) girl ) school ).

section.para: Even more versions could be created simply by placing any number of ke particles at the beginning of the phrase, and a like number of ke'e at its end. Obviously, all of these are a waste of breath once the left-grouping rule has been grasped. However, the following is equivalent to and may be easier to understand:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta - melbi - ke cmalu - nixli ke'e - - ckule
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-( pretty type-of ( little type-of girl ) ) type-of school.

section.para: Likewise, a ke and ke'e version of would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - cmalu ke nixli - ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(pretty type-of little) ( girl type-of school ).

section.para:
The final ke'e is given in square brackets here to indicate that it can be elided. It is always possible to elide
ke'e at the end of the predicate phrase, making as terse as .
Now how about that fifth grouping? It is

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - ke - cmalu - nixli - - ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-pretty type-of ( ( little type-of girl ) type-of school ).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a beautiful school for small girls.

section.para: is distinctly different in meaning from any of through . Note that within the ke…ke'e parentheses, the left-grouping rule is applied to cmalu nixli ckule.
tanru groupingwith ke and bo It is perfectly all right to mix bo and ke…ke'e in a single predicate. For instance, , which in pure ke…ke'e form is
can equivalently be expressed as:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta melbi - ke cmalu - nixli bo ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-pretty type-of ( little type-of-( girl type-of school )).

section.para: and in many other different forms as well.

section.title: Logical connection within tanru
section.para: The following particles are discussed in this section:
Consider the English phrase big red dog. How shall this be rendered as a Lojban tanru? The naive attempt:
will not do, as it means a dog whose redness is big, in whatever way redness might be described as big. Nor is

adjective ordering much better. After all, the straightforward understanding of the English phrase is that the dog is big as compared with other dogs, not merely as compared with other red dogs. In fact, the bigness and redness are independent properties of the dog, and only obscure rules of English adjective ordering prevent us from saying
red big dog.

logical connectivesin tanru The Lojban approach to this problem is to introduce the particle je, which is one of the many equivalents of English and. A big red dog is one that is both big and red, and we can say:
Of course,

logical connectives in tanrueffect on tanru grouping is equally satisfactory and means the same thing. As these examples indicate, joining two verbs with je makes them a unit for tanru purposes. However, explicit grouping with bo or ke…ke'e associates verbs more closely than je does:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: barda je pelxu bo xunre gerku
barda je ke pelxu - xunre ke'e gerku
interlinear-gloss.natlang: big yellowish-red dog

section.para: With no grouping indicators, we get:

interlinear-gloss.gloss: ((big and yellow) type-of red) type-of dog
interlinear-gloss.natlang: biggish- and yellowish-red dog

section.para: which again raises the question of : what does biggish-red mean?
logical connectives in tanruusefulness of Unlike bo and ke…ke'e, je is useful as well as merely legal within simple tanru. It may be used to partly resolve the ambiguity of simple tanru:

definitely refers to something which is both blue and is a house, and not to any of the other possible interpretations of simple blanu zdani. Furthermore, blanu zdani may refer to something which is blue in the way that houses are blue, but couldn't be called blue on its own, but there is no such option with blanu je zdani – the blueness of a blanu je zdani is independent of its houseness.
With the addition of je, many more versions of pretty little girls' school are made possible.
A subtle point in the semantics of tanru like needs special elucidation. There are at least two possible interpretations of:

interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(beautiful and girl) type-of school.

section.para: It can be understood as:

example.para: That is a girls' school and a beautiful school.

section.para: or as:

example.para: That is a school for things which are both girls and beautiful.

section.para: logical connectives in tanruambiguity of The interpretation specified by treats the tanru as a sort of abbreviation for:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta ke melbi - ckule ke'e je ke nixli - ckule [ke'e]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-( beautiful type-of school ) and ( girl type-of school )

section.para: whereas the interpretation specified by does not. This is a kind of semantic ambiguity for which Lojban does not compel a firm resolution. The way in which the school is said to be of type beautiful and girl may entail that it is separately a beautiful school and a girls' school; but the alternative interpretation, that the members of the school are beautiful and girls, is also possible. Still another interpretation is:

example.para: That is a school for beautiful things and also for girls.

section.para: so while the logical connectives help to resolve the meaning of tanru, they by no means compel a single meaning in and of themselves.
The logical connective je is only one of the fourteen logical connectives that Lojban provides. Here are a few examples of some of the others:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo bajra cu jinga ja toljinga
interlinear-gloss.natlang: the runner(s) is/are winner(s) or loser(s).
skin which is non-blue or cold
skin which is blue only if it is cold
speech which is good if (and only if) it is short
speech which is important, whether or not it is pleasing

section.para: In , ja is grammatically equivalent to je but means or (more precisely, and/or). Likewise, na ja means only if in , jo means if and only if in , and ju means whether or not in .
multiple logical connectiveswithin tanru Now consider the following example:

tanru grouping with JA+BOeffect on tanru grouping which illustrates a new grammatical feature: the use of both ja and bo between tanru components. The two particles combine to form a connective whose meaning is that of ja but which groups more closely; jabo is to
ja as plain bo is to no particle at all. However, both ja and jabo group less closely than
bo does:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ricfu je blanu ja--bo crino bo blanu
interlinear-gloss.natlang: rich and (blue or greenish-blue)

section.para: An alternative form of is:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ricfu je ke blanu ja crino [ke'e]

section.para: forethought logical connectiveswithin tanru Finally, just as English and has the variant form both … and, so je between tanru components has the variant form gu'e…gi, where gu'e is placed before the components and gi between them:
is equivalent in meaning to . For each logical connective related to je, there is a corresponding connective related to gu'e…gi in a systematic way.

forethought logical connectives in tanrueffect on tanru grouping The portion of a gu'e…gi construction before the gi is a full predicate phrase itself, so it can contain any of the tanru operators described here, including je logical connections. After the gi, logical connections are taken to be wider in scope than the gu'e…gi, which has in effect the same scope as bo:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: gu'e barda je xunre gi gerku ja mlatu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: (both (big and red) and dog) or cat
interlinear-gloss.natlang: something which is either big, red, and a dog, or else a cat

section.para: leaves mlatu outside the gu'e…gi construction. The scope of the gi arm extends only to a single verb or to two or more verbs connected with bo or ke…ke'e.

section.title: Linked arguments: be-bei-be'o
section.para: The following particles are discussed in this section:

The question of verbs' place structures has been glossed over so far. This chapter does not attempt to treat place structure issues in detail; they are discussed in . One grammatical structure related to places belongs here, however. In simple sentences such as , the place structure of the predicate is simply the defined place structure of mamta. What about more complex predicates?

tanruplace structures of For tanru, the place structure rule is simple: the place structure of a tanru is always the place structure of its tertau. Thus, the place structure of blanu zdani is that of zdani: the x1 place is a house or nest, and the x2 place is its occupants.

What about the places of blanu? Is there any way to get them into the act? In fact, blanu has only one place, and this is merged, as it were, with the x1 place of zdani. It is whatever is in the x1 place that is being characterized as blue-for-a-house. But if we replace blanu with cnino, we get:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is a new (to someone, in some aspect) house.

section.para: Since cnino has three places (x1, the new thing; x2, the person to whom it is new; and x3, the aspect in which it is new), necessarily omits information about the last two: there is no room for them. Room can be made, however!

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti cnino be do bei lo--ka blanu be'o zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-a-new (to you in being blue ) - house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is a house such that it being blue is new to you.

section.para: linked sumtiin tanru seltaufilling sumti places in Here, the verb cnino has been followed by the particle be (of class BE), which signals that one or more argument to the preceding verb follows. These arguments are not part of the main statement's place structure, but fill the places of the verb they are attached to, starting with x2. If there is more than one argument, they are separated by bei (of class BEI), and the list of arguments is terminated by the elidible terminator be'o (of class BEhO).

linked sumtidefinition Grammatically, a verb with argument phrases linked to it in this fashion plays the same role in tanru as a verb by itself. To illustrate, here is a more fleshed-out version of , with additional places filled in:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti cmalu be lo ka canlu
… nixli be li mu [be'o] bo ckule

interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is a school, small in volume for a school, pertaining to five-year-old girls, in Brooklyn, teaching poetry to the New York community and operated by the state.

section.para: Here three places of cmalu, two of nixli, and four of ckule are fully specified. Since the places of ckule are the places of the statement as a whole, it was not necessary to link the argument phrases following ckule. It would have been legal to do so, however:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be lo zarci bei lo zdani [be'o]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go ( to-the market - from-the house ).

section.para: means the same as

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama lo zarci lo zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I go to-the market from-the house.

section.para: tanruplace structures of No matter how complex a tanru gets, the last verb always dictates the place structure: the place structure of

interlinear-gloss.jbo: - melbi je cmalu nixli bo ckule
interlinear-gloss.natlang: a school for girls which is both beautiful and small

section.para: is simply that of ckule. (The sole exception to this rule is discussed in .)

FA tags and linked sumti linked sumti and FA tags It is possible to precede linked arguments by the place structure ordering tags
fe, fi, fo, and fu (of class FA, discussed further in ), which serve to explicitly specify the x2, x3, x4, and x5 places respectively. Normally, the place following the be is the x2 place and the other places follow in order. If it seems convenient to change the order, however, it can be accomplished as follows:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu be fi lo ka barda bei fe do [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: This is-a-good ( in-aspect the property-of bigness - for you ) house.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is a house that is good for you in that it is big.

section.para: Note that the order of be, bei, and be'o does not change; only the inserted fi tells us that mi is the x3 place (and correspondingly, the inserted fe tells us that do is the x2 place). Changing the order of arguments is often done to match the order of another language, for emphasis or rhythm, or to aid parsing by leaving deeply nested phrases till the end of a sentence.
Of course, using FA particles makes it easy to specify one place while omitting a previous place:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ti xamgu be fi mi [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.natlang: This is a good house by my standards.

section.para: sumti tcita and tense tags tense tags and sumti tcita sumti tcita and modal tags modal tags and sumti tcita sumti tcita and linked sumti linked sumti and sumti tcita Similarly, prepositional phrases, those specifying tense for example, can be inserted into strings of linked arguments just as they can into statements:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta blanu be ga'a mi [be'o] zdani
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a blue, as I see it, house.

section.para: The meaning of is slightly different from:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a blue house, as I see it.

section.para: See discussions in and in for more on prepositions.

be'oeffect of relative clauses on elidability of relative clauseseffect on elidability of be'o be'oelidability of elidability of be'o The terminator be'o can often be elided: however, a relative clause or a connective following an argument linked with be will attach to that argument unless
be'o is used, in which case it will attach to the outer description:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo xamgu be do noi barda cu zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The good-thing for you (who are-large) - is-a-house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo xamgu be do be'o noi barda cu zdani

section.para: (Relative clauses are explained in .)
be'oeffect of ku on elidability of kueffect on elidability of be'o In other cases, be'o cannot be elided if ku has also been elided:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo xamgu be lo ctuca [ku] be'o zdani

section.para: requires either ku or be'o, and since there is only one occurrence of be, the be'o must match it, whereas it may be confusing which occurrence of lo the ku terminates.

section.title: Inversion of tanru: co
section.para: The following particle is discussed in this section:

tanru inversion The standard order of Lojban tanru, whereby the modifier precedes what it modifies, is very natural to English-speakers: we talk of blue houses, not of houses blue. In other languages, however, such matters are differently arranged, and Lojban supports this reverse order (tertau before seltau) by inserting the particle co. and mean exactly the same thing:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a blue house.
That is a blue house.

section.para: place structure and tanru inversion tanru inversion and place structure The meaning, and more specifically, the place structure, of a tanru is not affected by inversion: the place structure of zdani co blanu is still conceptually that of zdani. However, the existence of inversion in a predicate phrase has a very special effect on any argument phrases that follow it. Instead of being interpreted as filling places of the main predicate (and thus the tertau), they actually fill the places (starting with x2) of the seltau. In , we saw how to fill interior places with be…bei…be'o, and in fact and have the same meaning:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be lo zarci bei lo zdani be'o troci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-(goer to the market from the house ) type-of-trier.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I try to go to the market from the house.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi troci co klama lo zarci lo zdani
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-trier of-type (goer to-the market from-the house).
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I try to go to the market from the house.

section.para: is a less deeply nested construction, requiring fewer particles. As a result it is probably easier to understand.

Note that in Lojban trying to go is expressed using troci as the tertau. The reason is that trying to go is a going type of trying, not a trying type of going. The trying is more fundamental than the going – if the trying fails, we may not have a going at all.

inverted tanrueffect on sumti after the selbri inverted tanrueffect on sumti before the selbri unfilled places of inverted tanru Any argument phrases preceding a predicate phrase with an inverted tanru fill the places of the whole predicate (i.e., the places of the tertau) in the ordinary way. In
, mi fills the x1 place of troci co klama, which is the x1 place of troci. Its other places remain unfilled. The trailing arguments lo zarci and lo zdani do not occupy places of the same predicate as mi, despite appearances.
As a result, the regular mechanisms (involving the vo'a and the go'a-series, explained in and ) for referring to individual arguments of a predication cannot refer to any of the trailing places of .

tanru inversionwhere allowed tanru inversionin complex tanru When inverting a more complex tanru, it is possible to invert it only at the most general modifier-modified pair. The only possible inversion of , for instance, is:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That's a girls' school, a small one.

section.para: tanru groupingeffect of tanru inversion on tanru inversioneffect on tanru grouping Note that the bo of is optional in , because co groups more broadly than any other connections used in tanru, including the case with no particles at all. Not even ke…ke'e parentheses can encompass a co:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ta cmalu - ke nixli - ckule [ke'e] co melbi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That is-a-(little type-of ( girl type-of school )) of-type pretty.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: That's a small school for girls which is beautiful.

section.para: tanru inversionrule for removing In , the ke'e is automatically inserted before the co rather than at its usual place at the end of the predicate phrase. As a result, there is a simple and mechanical rule for removing co from any predicate phrase: change A co B to ke B ke'e A. (At the same time, any following arguments must be transformed into be…bei…be'o form and attached following the ke'e.) Therefore,

interlinear-gloss.natlang: school for beautiful girls

section.para: means the same as:

multiple tanru inversioneffect on grouping tanru inversionmultiple Multiple co particles can appear within a predicate phrase, indicating multiple inversions: a right-grouping rule is employed, as for
bo. The above rule can be applied to interpret such phrases, but all co inversions must be removed simultaneously:
becomes formally

interlinear-gloss.jbo: ke ke cmalu ke'e nixli ke'e ckule

section.para: which by the left-grouping rule is simply

interlinear-gloss.natlang: school for little girls

section.para: As stated above, the argument places, other than the first, of

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go quickly

section.para: cannot be filled by placing argument phrases after the predicate phrase, because any arguments in that position fill the places of sutra, the seltau. However, the tertau places (which means in effect the whole tanru's places) can be filled by placing them in front of the predicate phrase, or with be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi klama be lo zarci be'o co cadzu
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I am-a-goer ( to-the store ) of-type walking.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I walk to the store.

section.title: Other kinds of tanru units
section.para: The following particles are discussed in this section:

cmavo-entry.description: changes number to ordinal predicate; n-th
changes number to cardinal predicate; n-some

section.para: equivalents to brivla brivla equivalents So far we have only discussed verbs and tanru built up from verbs as possible predicate phrases. In fact, there are a few other constructions in Lojban that can act as tanru units: they can be used either directly as main predicates, or as components in tanru. Some of these types of phrases are discussed at length in , , and ; but for completeness these types are mentioned here with a brief explanation and an example of their use.

tanruwith GOhA selbriwith GOhA GOhA selma'oas component in tanru GOhA selma'oas selbri The words of class GOhA (with one exception), morphologically particles but grammatically verbs, serve as pro-statements, providing a reference to the content of other sentences; none of them has a fixed meaning. The most commonly used member of GOhA is probably go'i, which amounts to a repetition of the previous sentence, or part of it. If I say:
you may retort:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: John tries to.

section.para: is short for:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .djan. cu klama be lo zarci be'o - troci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named John - is-a-goer ( to-the market ) type-of trier.

section.para: because the whole bridi of has been packaged up into the single word go'i and inserted into .
duas an exception within GOhA selma'o The exceptional member of GOhA is du, which represents the relation of identity. Its place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is identical with x2, x3, ...

section.para: for as many places as are given. More information on GOhA particles is available in .

tanrucontaining mathematical expressions mathematical expressions in tanru Lojban mathematical expressions (mekso) can be incorporated into predicates in two different ways. Mathematical operators such as
su'i, meaning plus, can be transformed into verbs by prefixing them with nu'a (of class NUhA). The resulting place structure is:

definition.content: x1 is the result of applying (the operator) to arguments x2, x3, etc.

section.para: for as many arguments as are required. (The result goes in the x1 place because the number of following places may be indefinite.) For example:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: li vo nu'a--su'i li re li re

section.para: A possible tanru example might be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi jimpe tu'a lo'e nu'a--su'i nabmi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I understand about the-typical is-the-sum-of problem.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I understand addition problems.

section.para:
MOI selma'o More usefully, it is possible to combine a mathematical expression with a particle of class MOI to create one of various numerical predicates. Details are available in
. Here are a few sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .prim. palvr. cu pa moi - lo tavla
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named Preem Palver - is-the-1 -th of the speakers.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Preem Palver is the first speaker.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo bruna be mi cu re mei
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The brothers of me - are-two in-number
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I have two brothers.

section.para: NU selma'o Finally, an important type of tanru unit made of multiple words is the abstraction. Grammatically, abstractions are simple: a particle of class NU, followed by a statement, followed by the elidible terminator kei of class KEI. Semantically, abstractions are an extremely subtle and powerful feature of Lojban whose full ramifications are documented in . A few examples:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: The cook is beautiful to me.

section.para: abstraction bridicontrasted with component non-abstraction bridi in meaning is quite distinct in meaning from:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo nu jukpa kei -- mi melbi
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The event-of-( cooking ) to me is-beautiful.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Cooking is beautiful to me.

section.title: Predicates based on arguments: me
section.para: The following particles are discussed in this section:

cmavo-entry.description: changes argument to predicate: x1 is among [argument]

section.para: meplace structure of conversion of sumti into selbri sumti into selbri selbri from sumti An argument phrase can be made into a tanru unit by preceding it with me (of class ME) and following it with the elidible terminator me'u (of class MEhU). This makes a predicate with the place structure

definition.content: x1 is/are among the referents of [the argument phrase]; x1 is/are among [the argument]

section.para: which is true of the thing, or any of the things, that the phrase refers to, and not of anything else. For example, consider the argument phrase

interlinear-gloss.natlang: the Three Kings

section.para: If these are understood to be the Three Kings of Christian tradition, who arrive every year on January 6, then we may say:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: Balthazar is one of the Three Kings.

section.para: and likewise

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: la .kaspar. jo'u la .melxyior. cu me la ci nolraitru
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Caspar and Melchior are among the Three Kings.

section.para: ducompared with me in effect mecompared with du in effect me/du equivalence If the argument phrase refers to a single object, then the effect of me is much like that of du:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are John.

section.para: means the same as

interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are John.

section.para: meused with cmevla It is common to use me predicates, especially those based on name-word arguments using la, as seltau. For example:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is a Chrysler car.

section.para: logical connectivesrelative precedence with me'u me'urelative precedence with logical connectives elidability of me'u The elidible terminator me'u can often be omitted. The cases where it is required are similar to those of be'o or lu'u, for example when a following relative clause () or connective () is meant to attach not to the argument of me, but to an outer argument phrase. Without a me'u, the relative clause or connective would belong to the argument embedded in the me expression. Here is a contrasting pair of sentences:

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: re me la ci nolraitru [ku] jo'u la .djan. [me'u] [ku] cu blabi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Two of [the Three kings and John] are white.

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: re me la ci nolraitru [ku] me'u [ku] jo'u la .djan. cu blabi
interlinear-gloss.natlang: [Two of the Three Kings], as well as John, are white.

section.para:
In the me predicate covers the Three Kings plus John, and the quantifier re picks out two of them that are said to be white: we cannot say which two. In
, though, the me predicate covers only the three kings: two of those are said to be white, and so is John.
Finally, here is another example with non-elidible me'u, which (unlike in the previous example) can be replaced with either of two other elided terminators:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: That is the kind of book you were talking about.

section.para: There are other sentences where either me'u or some other elidible terminator must be expressed:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: the Three Kings celebration

section.para: requires either ku or me'u to be explicit, and (as with be'o in ) the me'u leaves no doubt which cmavo it is paired with.

section.title: Conversion of predicates
section.para: xe ve te se SE selma'o place structurere-ordering by conversion conversiondefinition tanru and conversion conversion and tanru Conversion is the process of changing a predicate so that its places appear in a different order. This is not the same as labeling the arguments with FA particles, as mentioned in , and then rearranging the order in which they are spoken or written. Conversion transforms the predicate into a distinct, though regularly derived, predicate with renumbered places. Statements with converted predicates read much like natural language sentences in passive voice.
In Lojban, conversion is accomplished by placing a particle of class SE before a tanru unit:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I love you.

section.para: is equivalent in meaning to:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: You are loved by me.

section.para: Conversion is fully explained in . For the purposes of this chapter, the important point about conversion is that it applies only to the following tanru unit. When trying to convert a tanru, therefore, it is necessary to be careful! Consider :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu cadzu klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named Alice - is-a-walker type-of-goer-to the market.
That-named Alice - walkingly goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Alice walks to the market.

section.para: To convert this sentence so that lo zarci is in the x1 place, one correct way is:
kefor conversion of tanru conversion with ke The ke…ke'e brackets cause the entire tanru to be converted by the se, which would otherwise convert only cadzu, leading to:
whatever that might mean. An alternative approach, since the place structure of cadzu klama is that of klama alone, is to convert only the latter:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: lo zarci cu cadzu se--klama la .alis.
interlinear-gloss.gloss: The market - walkingly is-gone-to-by that-named Alice.

section.para: But the tanru in may or may not have the same meaning as that in ; in particular, because cadzu is not converted, there is a suggestion that although Alice is the goer, the market is the walker. With a different argument as x1, this seemingly odd interpretation might make considerable sense:

interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named John - walkingly is-gone-to-by that-named Alice

section.para: suggests that Alice is going to John, who is a moving target.

tense conversionwith jai jaifor modal conversion There is another type of conversion, using the particle jai of class JAI optionally followed by a preposition. Grammatically, such a combination behaves exactly like conversion using SE. More details can be found in .

section.title: Scalar negation of predicates
section.para: selbriscalar negation of scalar negationeffect on selbri Negation is too large and complex a topic to explain fully in this chapter; see . In brief, there are two main types of negation in Lojban. This section is concerned with so-called scalar negation, which is used to state that a true relation between the arguments is something other than what the (bare) predicate specifies. Scalar negation is expressed by particles of class NAhE:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu na'e ke cadzu klama [ke'e] lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named Alice - non- ( walkingly goes-to ) the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Alice doesn't walk to the market.
Alice does something other to the market than walk to it.

section.para: kefor expanding scope of scalar negation meaning that Alice's relationship to the market is something other than that of walking there. But if the ke were omitted, the result would be:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: la .alis. cu na'e cadzu klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: That-named Alice - non- walkingly goes-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: Alice doesn't walk to the market.
Alice doesn't walk to the market.

section.para: meaning that Alice does go there in some way (klama is not negated), but by a means other than that of walking. negates both cadzu and klama, suggesting that Alice's relation to the market is something different from walkingly-going; it might be walking without going, or going without walking, or neither.
Of course, any of the tanru unit types explained in may be used in place of verbs in any of these examples.

negationcomplex examples complex negationexamples Here is an assortment of more complex examples showing the interaction of scalar negation with normal grouping, ke and ke'e grouping, logical connection, and arguments linked with be and bei:na'econtrasted with na'e ke

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e sutra cadzu be fi lo birka be'o klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I ((non- quickly) (walking - using the arms )) go-to the market.
interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, walking using my arms other than quickly.

section.para: In , na'e negates only sutra. Contrast :

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi lo birka [be'o]
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non- ( quickly (walking - using the arms )

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, other than by walking quickly on my arms.

section.para: Now consider and , which are equivalent in meaning, but use bo grouping and ke grouping respectively:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi sutra bo cadzu be fi lo birka be'o

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, both quickly walking using my arms and slowly.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi ke sutra cadzu be fi lo birka [be'o] ke'e

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, both quickly walking using my arms and slowly.

section.para: However, if we place a na'e at the beginning of the predicate phrase in both and , we get different results:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e sutra cadzu be fi lo birka be'o

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, both walking using my arms other than quickly, and also slowly.

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi lo birka [be'o] ke'e

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I go to the market, both other than quickly walking using my arms, and also slowly.

section.para: The difference arises because the na'e in negates the whole construction from ke to ke'e, whereas in it negates sutra alone.

perils of omitting terminators omitting terminatorsperils of Beware of omitting terminators in these complex examples! If the explicit
ke'e is left out in , it is transformed into:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi lo birka be'o
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non- ( quickly ((walking - using the arms) )

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I do something other than quickly both going to the market walking using my arms and slowly going to the market.

section.para: And if both ke'e and be'o are omitted, the results are even sillier:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na'e ke sutra cadzu be fi lo birka je masno
interlinear-gloss.gloss: I non ( quickly walk - on (the arm-type and slow)

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I do something to the market other than quickly walking on it using the goers, both arm-type and slow.

section.para:
In , everything after be is a linked argument phrase, so the place structure is that of
cadzu, whose x2 place is the surface walked upon. It is less than clear what an arm-type goer might be. Furthermore, since the linked argument occupies the third place of cadzu, the
lo zarci following the predicate phrase falls into its still-unfilled x2 place. As a result, the whole example, though grammatical, is nonsense. (The bracketed Lojban words appear where a fluent Lojbanist would understand them to be implied.)
na'ebefore gu'e Finally, it is also possible to place na'e before a gu'e…gi logically connected tanru construction, with no need for an intervening ke.

section.title: Tenses and contradictory negation
section.para: A statement can have particles associated with it which specify the time, place, or mode of action. For example, in

interlinear-gloss.natlang: I went to the market.

section.para: the particle pu specifies that the action of the speaker going to the market takes place in the past. Tenses are explained in full detail in . Tense is semantically a property of the entire statement; however, the usual syntax for tenses attaches them at the front of the selbri, as in . There are alternative ways of expressing tense information as well. Words like pu, often called tags, or in Lojban, sumtcita, act as adverbs when placed before the predicate phrase, or as prepositions when placed before an argument phrase. More on that in .

Similarly, a statement may have the particle na (of class NA) attached to the predicate phrase to negate the bridi. A statement negated with na expresses what is false without saying anything about what is true. Do not confuse this usage with the scalar negation of . For example:

interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is not true that Jones is the first speaker.
Jones isn't the first speaker.

section.para: bridi negationrelative order with tense tenserelative order with bridi negation Various combinations of tense and negation particles are permitted; each following particle can be thought of as starting a new statement that previous particles comment on:

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: mi na pu klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is false that: in the past: I go to the market.
I didn't go to the market [at all].

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: mi pu na klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: In the past: it is false that: I go to the market.
[At some point,] I wasn't going to the market.

section.para: bridi negationmultiple It is also possible to have more than one na, in which case pairs of na cancel out:

interlinear-gloss.jbophrase: mi na na klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is false that it is false that I go to the market.
I go to the market.

section.para: tense and namultiple na and tensemultiple It is also possible to have multiple na particles and tags mixed together:

interlinear-gloss.jbo: mi na ba'o na pu klama lo zarci
interlinear-gloss.natlang: It is false that: it is no longer the case that: it is false that: in the past: I go to the market.
I'm not past the stage in which I haven't yet gone to the market.
I still haven't been to the market.

section.para: negation cmavoposition relative to selbri modal cmavoposition relative to selbri tense cmavoposition relative to selbri Tense and negation particles in their bare, adverb-like form, can appear only at the beginning of the predicate phrase.

section.title: Some types of asymmetrical tanru
section.para: tanruasymmetrical asymmetrical tanru This section and contain some example tanru classified into groups based on the type of relationship between the modifying seltau and the modified tertau. All the examples are paralleled by compounds actually observed in various natural languages. In the tables which follow, each group is preceded by a brief explanation of the relationship. The tables themselves contain a tanru, a literal gloss, an indication of the languages which exhibit a compound analogous to this tanru, and (for those tanru with no English parallel) a translation.

languagesabbreviations for Here are the 3-letter abbreviations used for the various languages (it is presumed to be obvious whether a compound is found in English or not, so English is not explicitly noted):
Any compounds or loanwords used in a group are glossed at the end of that group.

asymmetrical tanrudefinition The tanru discussed in this section are asymmetrical tanru; that is, ones in which the order of the terms is fundamental to the meaning of the tanru. For example,
junla dadysli, or clock pendulum, is the kind of pendulum used in a clock, whereas dadysli junla, or pendulum clock, is the kind of clock that employs a pendulum. Most tanru are asymmetrical in this sense. Symmetrical tanru are discussed in .
asymmetrical tanru typesobject-of-action + action The tertau represents an action, and the seltau then represents the object of that action:
asymmetrical tanru typeselements-in-set + set The tertau represents a set, and the seltau the type of the elements contained in that set:

asymmetrical tanru typesset + element-of-set Conversely: the tertau is an element, and the seltau represents a set in which that element is contained. Implicitly, the meaning of the tertau is restricted from its usual general meaning to the specific meaning appropriate for elements in the given set. Note the opposition between zdani lijgri in the previous group, and lijgri zdani in this one, which shows why this kind of tanru is called asymmetrical.

asymmetrical tanru typesobject + component/detail The seltau specifies an object and the tertau a component or detail of that object; the tanru as a whole refers to the detail, specifying that it is a detail of that whole and not some other.

asymmetrical tanru typescharacteristic/detail + object Conversely: the seltau specifies a characteristic or important detail of the object described by the tertau; objects described by the tanru as a whole are differentiated from other similar objects by this detail.
asymmetrical tanru typesgeneral-class + sub-class The tertau specifies a general class of object (a genus), and the seltau specifies a sub-class of that class (a species):

asymmetrical tanru typespossessor + object The tertau specifies an object of possession, and the seltau may specify the possessor (the possession may be intrinsic or otherwise). In English, these compounds have an explicit possessive element in them: lion's mane, child's foot, noble's cow.
asymmetrical tanru typesinhabitant + habitat The tertau specifies a habitat, and the seltau specifies the inhabitant:
asymmetrical tanru typeseffect + causative agent The tertau specifies a causative agent, and the seltau specifies the effect of that cause:
asymmetrical tanru typescause + effect Conversely: the tertau specifies an effect, and the seltau specifies its cause.
asymmetrical tanru typespurpose-of-instrument + instrument The tertau specifies an instrument, and the seltau specifies the purpose of that instrument:

asymmetrical tanru typesobject-of-purpose-of-instrument + instrument More vaguely: the tertau specifies an instrument, and the seltau specifies the object of the purpose for which that instrument is used:
asymmetrical tanru typessource + product The tertau specifies a product from some source, and the seltau specifies the source of the product:
asymmetrical tanru typesproduct + source Conversely: the tertau specifies the source of a product, and the seltau specifies the product:

asymmetrical tanru typessource-material + object The tertau specifies an object, and the seltau specifies the material from which the object is made. This case is especially interesting, because the referent of the tertau may normally be made from just one kind of material, which is then overridden in the tanru.
Note: the two senses of blaci kanla can be discriminated as:

asymmetrical tanru typesobject-measured + standard-object The tertau specifies a typical object used to measure a quantity and the seltau specifies something measured. The tanru as a whole refers to a given quantity of the thing being measured. English does not have compounds of this form, as a rule.

asymmetrical tanru typesoverriding-property + object-with-implicit-properties The tertau specifies an object with certain implicit properties, and the seltau overrides one of those implicit properties:

asymmetrical tanru typeswhole + part The seltau specifies a whole, and the tertau specifies a part which normally is associated with a different whole. The tanru then refers to a part of the seltau which stands in the same relationship to the whole seltau as the tertau stands to its typical whole.

asymmetrical tanru typesproduct + producer The tertau specifies the producer of a certain product, and the seltau specifies the product. In this way, the tanru as a whole distinguishes its referents from other referents of the tertau which do not produce the product.

asymmetrical tanru typesobject-giving-characteristic + other-object The tertau specifies an object, and the seltau specifies another object which has a characteristic property. The tanru as a whole refers to those referents of the tertau which possess the property.
asymmetrical tanru typessimilar-appearance-object + object As a particular case (when the property is that of resemblance): the seltau specifies an object which the referent of the tanru resembles.
asymmetrical tanru typestypical-place + object The seltau specifies a place, and the tertau an object characteristically located in or at that place.
asymmetrical tanru typesobject + place-sold Specifically: the tertau is a place where the seltau is sold or made available to the public.
asymmetrical tanru typeslocus-of-application + object The seltau specifies the locus of application of the tertau.
asymmetrical tanru typesactivity + implement-used The tertau specifies an implement used in the activity denoted by the seltau.
asymmetrical tanru typesundesired-object + protection-object The tertau specifies a protective device against the undesirable features of the referent of the seltau.
asymmetrical tanru typesobject + usual-container The tertau specifies a container characteristically used to hold the referent of the seltau.
asymmetrical tanru typescharacteristic-time + event The seltau specifies the characteristic time of the event specified by the tertau.
asymmetrical tanru typesenergy-source + powered The seltau specifies a source of energy for the referent of the tertau.
asymmetrical tanru typesmiscellaneous Finally, some tanru which don't fall into any of the above categories.

It is clear that tooth is being specified, and that milk and eye act as modifiers. However, the relationship between ladru and denci is something like tooth which one has when one is drinking milk from one's mother, a relationship certainly present nowhere except in this particular concept. As for kanla denci, the relationship is not only not present on the surface, it is hardly possible to formulate it at all.

section.title: Some types of symmetrical tanru
section.para: symmetrical tanru This section deals with symmetrical tanru, where order is not important. Many of these tanru can be expressed with a logical or non-logical connective between the components.

symmetrical tanru typesboth separately true The tanru may refer to things which are correctly specified by both tanru components. Some of these instances may also be seen as asymmetrical tanru where the seltau specifies a material. The connective
je is appropriate:
symmetrical tanru typesone or other true The tanru may refer to all things which are specified by either of the tanru components. The connective ja is appropriate:

symmetrical tanru typesusing more inclusive class Alternatively, the tanru may refer to things which are specified by either of the tanru components or by some more inclusive class of things which the components typify:
symmetrical tanru typesusing crucial/typical parts The tanru components specify crucial or typical parts of the referent of the tanru as a whole:
